content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Kelly Sullivan: Well, I was born and raised in Charleston, South Carolina, in a small, working-class neighborhood. My parents both grew up in the South Atlantic region too, and they worked hard to make ends meet. I remember my childhood being pretty straightforward—nothing fancy, but full of love and family. We lived in a modest house on Elm Street, and my dad worked construction while my mom worked part-time at a local store. Both of them only made it through high school, so education wasn't really something they could talk about with much confidence. I was the first in my family to graduate from high school, which was a big deal for them. I always felt like I had to prove myself, not just to them, but to the world. After high school, I tried a few things—worked at a diner, then a retail store—but nothing really stuck. I've been laid off a few times, and it's been tough trying to find steady work, especially with the economy the way it is. I'm still looking, though, and I'm trying to figure out what I want to do next. I've always been independent, and I think that's why I never really identified with any political party. I just want things to be fair for everyone, you know?

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Kelly Sullivan: There was one moment that really shaped me, and it happened right after I graduated high school. I was 18, and I had this idea that if I worked hard enough, I could get out of the cycle my parents were in. I applied to a few community colleges, but I was also working full-time at a diner to help support my family. I remember one night, after working a double shift, I was sitting on the porch, looking at the stars, and I realized I didn't want to just survive—I wanted to have a real future. That's when I decided to take a chance and move to a different city for a while, to see what else was out there. I ended up in Charlotte for a few months, working at a retail store and taking night classes. It was tough, but I met people who were going to college and talking about their dreams. That's when I realized I needed to go back to school, even if it meant starting over. I came back to Charleston, enrolled in a GED program, and eventually got my high school diploma. That moment on the porch was the crossroads—choosing to keep going instead of settling. It changed everything for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Kelly Sullivan: I think it was a conscious choice, but it felt like something inside me just clicked. I didn't have a plan, but I knew I couldn't stay in that same place forever. It was like I was holding my breath for so long, and finally, I let it out. I remember telling my mom that night, 'I'm not going to let this be my life.' She didn't say much, just hugged me and said, 'I believe in you.' That meant more than anything. I didn't have a lot of resources, but I had that moment of clarity, and I made a decision to push forward. It wasn't easy, but I think that's what makes it real—knowing you're choosing to change, even when the path isn't clear.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Kelly Sullivan: Yeah, I think someone or something could have helped, but I also think a lot of people in my situation don't even know where to start asking. I remember talking to a counselor at the community center once, and she suggested some job training programs, but I was too scared to take the next step. I felt like I didn't have the time or the resources. If someone had really sat down with me and helped me see the options, maybe I wouldn't have spent so much time bouncing between jobs. But I also know that I had to take the first step myself. It's a tough balance between needing help and wanting to prove you can do it on your own.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Kelly Sullivan: I don't have a partner or children right now. My family is my mom and dad, and my younger brother, Sean. He's 19 and just finished his first year of college online. He's the one who really pushed me to keep going after I came back from Charlotte. He'd always say, 'You can do better than this, Kelly.' It's funny, because I used to think I was the responsible one, but now I see how much he's grown. My parents are still living in the same house on Elm Street, and even though things are tight, they always make sure I know I'm not alone. I visit them as much as I can, and we still have those late-night talks on the porch, just like when I was younger. I guess I'm still figuring out what I want for myself, but I know I want to make sure my family is proud of me, and that I can be there for them when they need me.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my life from the beginning made me realize how far I've come, even if I'm still figuring things out. That moment on the porch after high school, when I decided to take control of my future, still feels like the turning point that defined who I am today. It wasn't easy, and I wish I had more support back then, but I also know I had to take that first step on my own. Now, seeing my brother grow and push forward, I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can be there for him the way he was there for me. I guess I'm still searching for my path, but I'm grateful for the people who've stood by me along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Kelly Sullivan: My uncle Mark lives in Atlanta, and he's the only one in the family who really pushed for education. He was the first to go to college, and he ended up working in IT. He always kept in touch, even when we were kids, and he'd send us books or talk to us about what he was learning. I used to think he was kind of a nerd, but now I see how much he sacrificed to get out of our situation. We don't talk as much these days, but when we do, it's always about family and what we're trying to build for ourselves. I wish I had reached out to him more when I was struggling, but I guess I was too proud or didn't know where to start. Still, I'm grateful for him—he's always believed in me, even when I didn't believe in myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Kelly Sullivan: There's this friend of mine, Jamie, who I met when I was working at the diner in Charlotte. She was a barista there too, but she had this way of making everyone feel seen, even if they were just passing through. We bonded over late-night shifts and our shared frustration with the system. She ended up moving back to Charleston a few years ago and started a small nonprofit that helps people like me—people who are trying to get back on their feet but don't know where to start. I've been volunteering with her a bit, just helping out with administrative stuff, and it's been really rewarding. Jamie's the kind of person who doesn't just talk about change; she lives it. She's the one who reminded me that I don't have to do it all alone. I think I owe a lot of my strength to her, even if I didn't realize it at the time.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Kelly Sullivan: I live in a neighborhood just a few blocks away from where I grew up, but it's a bit different now. There are more apartments and small businesses popping up, which is kind of cool. It's still pretty working-class, though, and I feel like I fit in here. I rent a small apartment above a bakery, and the owner, Mrs. Delgado, is like a second mom to me. She always brings me pastries when I'm struggling and listens when I need to talk. The area isn't perfect—there are some issues with crime and not enough job opportunities—but there's a real sense of community. People look out for each other, even if they don't know you well. I like that about it. It reminds me of home, but also feels like a fresh start. I'm trying to make the most of it, even if I'm not sure where I'm headed yet.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Kelly Sullivan: I feel safe here, mostly. There are moments when I worry, especially at night when I hear things outside my apartment, but I've learned to be cautious. The neighborhood has its challenges, but I think the sense of community helps keep things from getting too bad. People know each other, and there's a kind of unspoken agreement to look out for one another. I've never had anything bad happen to me, and I think that's partly because I try to be respectful and keep my head down. I know it's not the safest place in the world, but it's home, and I'm not ready to leave it just yet.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Kelly Sullivan: It's been a mix of things, really. On one hand, I love the familiarity of being close to home. I know the streets, I know the people, and there's a comfort in that. But on the other hand, it can feel like I'm stuck in a loop sometimes. I see the same faces, go to the same places, and it's easy to feel like I'm not making progress. But I also know that I'm not the only one here trying to figure things out. There's a lot of people in this neighborhood who are working hard, just like me, and that gives me hope. I think the key is to keep moving forward, even if it's just one step at a time. I'm learning to be patient with myself, and I'm trying to focus on the little wins—like getting a job interview or helping Jamie with her nonprofit. I don't know what the future holds, but I'm trying to make the most of where I am right now.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots still shape who I am, even as I try to build something new. Talking about my mom, dad, and brother reminded me of how much they've supported me, even when I didn't always see it. My brother, Sean, has always been the one pushing me forward, and now I feel like I can be that same kind of support for him. As for my neighborhood, it's not perfect, but it's home. I know there are challenges, but there's also a real sense of community that keeps me grounded. I may not have everything figured out yet, but I'm learning to find strength in the people and places that have always been there for me.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Kelly Sullivan: A typical week for me is pretty much the same, but there are little variations depending on what I'm working on. I usually start my day around 7 or 8 in the morning, after a few hours of sleep. I work part-time at a small bookstore downtown, which is nice because it's quiet and the customers are pretty friendly. I usually work mornings, so I have the afternoons free to catch up on things. Some days I'll spend time helping Jamie with her nonprofit, sorting donations or organizing events. Other days, I'll just sit at the library and study for my GED or look into online courses I can take. I try to go to the community center a couple of times a week too—they have some free workshops on job skills and resume building. I've been going to one on communication, and it's been really helpful. I also make sure to visit my parents at least once a week, usually on weekends. We'll have dinner, talk about life, and sometimes just sit on the porch like we used to. It's not the most exciting life, but it's steady, and I'm learning to find value in the little things.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Kelly Sullivan: I work part-time at a small bookstore downtown, usually mornings from 9 to 12, and then I have afternoons free to focus on other things. The bookstore is run by an older couple, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson, and they've been really kind to me. They let me take my time with the customers and even gave me a little discount on books I want to keep for myself. It's not a lot of money, but it's steady, and I like the quiet of it. I've always loved reading, so it feels like I'm doing something I enjoy while still earning a paycheck. I also do some odd jobs around the neighborhood—helping with yard work, running errands, that kind of thing. It's not glamorous, but it helps cover the bills and gives me a little flexibility. I'm trying to keep things simple, you know? Just enough to get by and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Kelly Sullivan: Yeah, I also have this routine of going for walks in the evenings, especially when the weather is nice. It helps me clear my head and think about things. I usually take the same path down by the river, past the old park where I used to play as a kid. It's funny how the place looks different now, but I still feel connected to it. I also try to keep a journal these days, just jotting down thoughts or ideas that come to me. It's not anything formal, just a way to track my progress and remind myself why I'm doing this. And every now and then, I'll call my uncle Mark or check in with Jamie, just to make sure I'm not losing sight of where I want to go. It's not much, but these little things help me stay grounded and keep moving forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Kelly Sullivan: Well, lately, I've started getting up a little earlier, maybe around 6:30 or 7, just to have some quiet time before the day gets going. I've been trying to read more, especially books that might help me with my GED or just give me something to think about. I also signed up for an online course in basic computer skills, which I'm taking in the evenings after work. It's been a bit of a challenge keeping up with the schedule, but I'm trying my best. I've also been helping Jamie with her nonprofit more regularly now—she's planning a community workshop on resume writing, and I'm going to be one of the facilitators. It's a little nerve-wracking, but I'm excited to do something that might actually help people in our neighborhood. I guess I'm just trying to find more balance in my days, and maybe take a few more steps toward something bigger.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Kelly Sullivan: I don't have children yet, but I think about it sometimes. I know my brother Sean is focused on his studies, and I want to be there for him the way he was there for me. If I did have kids, I'd want them to feel supported and encouraged, just like I did. I'd probably start their day early, maybe with some breakfast and reading, and make sure they had time to explore their interests. I'd love for them to have the chance to go to college, just like Sean, and I'd do everything I could to help them get there. I guess I'm still figuring out what that looks like for me, but I know I want to be a good example and give them the kind of support I wish I'd had when I was younger.

Going through those interview questions made me think a lot about how my life has been shaped by the people and places I've known. It's funny how much I take for granted the little things—the late-night talks with my parents on the porch, the support from my brother, the quiet encouragement from my uncle, and even the small kindnesses from people in my neighborhood. I used to feel like I was stuck in a cycle, but now I see how much I've grown, even if I'm still figuring things out. I think the most important thing I've learned is that I don't have to do it all alone. People like Jamie, my family, and even the people at the community center have played a role in helping me move forward. I'm still searching for my path, but I'm starting to believe that it's okay to take it one step at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, my health hasn't been the best, especially with everything I've been going through. I used to be pretty active as a kid, always running around with my brother or helping my dad with odd jobs around the house. But over the years, with the stress of trying to find work and keep things going, I've been more sedentary. I don't get much exercise these days, and I've started noticing it in my energy levels. I used to be able to work long hours without tiring, but now I get exhausted pretty easily. I also struggle with anxiety sometimes, especially when I'm feeling stuck or unsure about the future. I've been trying to take better care of myself lately—eating more regularly, getting enough sleep, and even going for those walks in the evenings. I know it's not much, but it's a start. I guess I just hope I can keep moving forward, both physically and mentally, so I can be there for my family and not let my own struggles hold me back.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Kelly Sullivan: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that small things matter—like those walks by the river, or just taking a few minutes to breathe before starting my day. It's the little habits that add up, even if I don't feel like I'm doing much. What makes it hard, though, is the constant worry about the future and not having a clear path. When I'm stressed or unsure, I tend to skip meals or push through exhaustion because I feel like I don't have time to take care of myself. I guess it's a cycle—feeling tired makes me less motivated to move, and not moving makes me feel even worse. But I'm trying to break that cycle, one step at a time. I know I can't change everything overnight, but I'm learning that taking care of my health is part of taking care of my future, and that's something I can control.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, I haven't had any major health issues in the past two years, but there have been a few things that stood out. About a year ago, I started having some back pain, probably from sitting too long at the bookstore or hunching over my GED materials. I didn't think much of it at first, just dismissed it as stress or poor posture. But then one day, I woke up and couldn't stand up straight without a sharp pain. I went to the clinic, and the doctor said it was a mild strain, but he also mentioned that I needed to start stretching and taking more breaks. I tried, but it's been hard to stay consistent. I also had a few flare-ups of anxiety around the time I started helping Jamie with her nonprofit. It was a lot to take on, and I felt like I was juggling too many things at once. I didn't want to let her down, but I also didn't want to burn myself out. I've been seeing a counselor at the community center now, and it's been helping me manage that anxiety a bit better. I guess I'm learning that taking care of my health isn't just about physical things—it's also about mental and emotional well-being, and I'm trying to be more aware of that now.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, it's been a challenge, but I've learned to adapt. The back pain has made some days harder, especially when I'm on my feet for long periods at the bookstore or helping with Jamie's nonprofit. I've had to pace myself more, take more breaks, and sometimes say no to extra work when I need to rest. The anxiety has also made it harder to focus at times, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed with everything. But I've found that talking to the counselor at the community center has helped me manage it better. I've also started setting small goals for myself, like walking for 20 minutes a day or making sure I eat a proper meal before work. It's not perfect, but it's helping me stay on track. I know I can't control everything, but I can control how I respond to it. And as long as I can keep going, even if it's slow, I feel like I'm making progress.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Kelly Sullivan: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—hope, frustration, and a little bit of uncertainty. There are days when I feel like I'm making progress, like when I finally passed my GED or when I got to help Jamie with her workshop. Those moments make me feel like I'm actually doing something, like I'm moving forward instead of just staying in place. But there are other days when I feel stuck, like when I'm sitting at the bookstore, looking at the same books I've seen a hundred times, and wondering if I'm ever going to get out of this cycle. I've been trying to be more patient with myself, though. I know it's not easy to change things overnight, and I'm learning that it's okay to take small steps. I've also been trying to focus more on the people around me—my family, Jamie, even the people at the community center. They've all been there for me, and I think that's what's keeping me going. I don't know what's next, but I'm trying to believe that it will be better.

Going through those recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my daily life has changed—and how much it hasn't. Talking about my routine, my job at the bookstore, and the small steps I'm taking with my GED and Jamie's nonprofit reminded me that I'm not as far behind as I sometimes feel. It also made me think about my health, and how I've been neglecting it for so long. I used to be more active, more present in my own life, but the stress of trying to find my way has taken a toll. I'm learning, though, that taking care of myself isn't just about big changes—it's about the little things, like getting up a little earlier, walking by the river, or even just eating a proper meal before work. I'm still figuring it all out, but I'm starting to believe that I can take control of my future, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Kelly Sullivan: I think I've dealt with anxiety more than anything else, and sometimes it feels like it's always been there, just in the background. There were times when I didn't even realize how much it was affecting me—like when I was bouncing between jobs or feeling like I wasn't good enough. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, I could ignore it. But over the past year, I've started to see it for what it is. It's not a sign that I'm failing; it's just part of trying to navigate a life that feels uncertain. I've been going to the counselor at the community center, and it's helped me understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, to feel like I'm not enough, or like I'm not moving fast enough. I used to think I had to be strong all the time, but now I see that being honest about my struggles is a kind of strength too. I'm still learning how to manage it, but I'm trying not to let it define me. I want to be more than my anxiety, and I think that's the first step.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Kelly Sullivan: My family has been through a lot, but they've always been there for me, even when they didn't have much to give. My mom and dad, they've never said much about their own struggles, but I can see it in the way they work so hard to keep things going. They never wanted me to feel like I had to stay in the same place they were in, and I think that's why they were always pushing me to do better. My brother Sean, he's been the biggest support system for me—always encouraging me to keep going, even when I felt like I wasn't making progress. He's the one who reminded me that I wasn't alone in this. As for my parents, they've been trying to adjust to the changes in our lives, especially with Sean going to college and me trying to find my way. They worry about us, but they also know we're trying our best. I think the hardest part for them is watching us struggle, but they've always believed in us. I just hope I can make them proud, not just for what I achieve, but for the way I keep going, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Kelly Sullivan: I don't really think about religion or spirituality in the way some people do. I was raised in a household where faith wasn't really a big part of daily life—my parents didn't go to church, and we didn't talk about it much. I guess I never felt like I needed it, not because I didn't believe in something, but because I always felt like I had to rely on myself and the people around me. There were times when I felt like the world was too big and too unfair, and I wondered if there was something bigger out there, but I never really found a place for that in my life. What I do believe in, though, is the strength of the people I love—the way my family has always supported me, even when they didn't have much to give. I think that's my kind of faith, if that makes sense. It's not about religion, but about knowing that I'm not alone, and that even when things feel impossible, there's always someone who believes in me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, I don't use social media much. I know people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through posts and stories, but I've never really felt the need for it. I guess I'm more of a quiet person, and I find that the more I'm online, the more I feel like I'm comparing myself to others. I've seen posts from friends who are traveling, working at cool jobs, or just living this perfect life, and it makes me feel like I'm falling behind. I don't want to feel that way, so I've mostly kept my distance. I do use Facebook sometimes to stay in touch with family, especially my uncle Mark and my brother Sean. I'll check in with them, see what they're up to, and maybe share a photo or two from my walks by the river. But other than that, I prefer to keep things simple. I think I'm more connected to the people in my life through real conversations, even if they're just late-night talks on the porch. I don't need a screen to feel like I'm part of something bigger.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Kelly Sullivan: I guess I haven't really relied on social media for support, but I can see how it might help some people. I know Jamie uses it to promote her nonprofit and connect with others who need help, and she says it's been a big part of what she's built. For me, though, I've always found support in the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, even the people at the community center. I don't need to see someone's perfect life online to feel like I'm not alone. When I'm struggling, I call my brother or talk to my mom, and that's enough. I think I've always believed that real connections matter more than what you see on a screen. I don't know if that makes me old-fashioned or just stubborn, but I'm not ready to trade those real conversations for likes and comments any time soon.

Going through those recent interview questions made me think a lot about how much my health has affected my life, both physically and mentally. It's strange how something as simple as back pain or anxiety can make days feel heavier, like I'm carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. I used to ignore those feelings, thinking I could push through them, but now I see that taking care of my health isn't just about being strong—it's about being honest with myself and asking for help when I need it. I've been learning to slow down, to take small steps, and to not be so hard on myself when things don't go as planned. It's not easy, but I'm starting to believe that I can heal, not just physically, but emotionally too. And even though I still have a long way to go, I'm grateful for the people who've been there for me, like my counselor, my family, and Jamie. They've reminded me that I don't have to face this alone, and that's something I need to keep holding on to.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, my stress levels have been a bit all over the place lately. Some days I feel like I'm making progress, like when I finally got that GED or when I helped Jamie with her workshop, and it makes me feel like I'm actually doing something. But other days, I feel like I'm just spinning my wheels, stuck in the same routine, not sure if I'm getting anywhere. I've been trying to manage it better, though. I've started talking to my counselor more regularly, and it's helped me realize that it's okay to feel overwhelmed. I've also been trying to focus on small, achievable goals—like walking for 20 minutes a day or making sure I eat a proper meal before work. It's not much, but it helps me feel like I'm in control of something, even if it's just a little. I've also been leaning more on my family and Jamie, knowing that I don't have to face this alone. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to take it one step at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Kelly Sullivan: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and the cost of my GED materials. Rent is the biggest chunk—my apartment above the bakery is pretty affordable, but it still takes up about half of my income. Groceries are tricky because I try to eat healthy but don't always have the budget for fresh produce. I end up buying a lot of canned goods and staples to stretch my dollars. The GED materials weren't too bad, but I had to pay for a few online courses and a textbook, which added up. I also had to set aside some money for my mom and dad's bills, just to help out a little. It's a tight budget, but I manage by cutting back on things like eating out or buying new clothes. I know it's not much, but I'm trying to be responsible and not take on more debt. It's hard to feel like I'm making progress when I'm just trying to keep up with the basics, but I'm learning to be more mindful of every dollar I spend.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, it's been tough to keep track of exactly how much we spend each month because I'm always adjusting based on what's coming in. Last month, I'd say we spent around $1,500 total, give or take. That's pretty much the usual, though it can fluctuate depending on how much I'm working or if I have to pay for something unexpected, like a new pair of shoes or a doctor's visit. Most of that goes to rent, groceries, and utilities, and then there's the little bit I set aside for my parents' bills. I try to keep a budget in my head, but it's not always easy when things come up. I know it's not a lot, but I'm trying to be careful with every dollar. I just hope that one day, I can get to a point where I don't have to worry about money as much, but for now, I'm just focused on making it work.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Kelly Sullivan: We rent our home, actually. I live in a small apartment above a bakery on the same street where I grew up, just a few blocks away from my parents' house. It's not much, but it's affordable and it feels like a safe space. Rent is the biggest part of my budget, and I try to keep things simple there—just a small bedroom, a kitchenette, and a little living area. I don't own anything much, just a few clothes, some books, and a few things I've picked up over the years. I know it's not the most stable situation, but it's something I can manage on my own. I've never been one for big things or fancy stuff—I think I'm more of a 'keep it simple' kind of person. Plus, being close to home makes it easier to help my family when they need it, and that's something I value more than anything else.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Kelly Sullivan: Over the past year, my bills have definitely gone up and down depending on the season and what's going on. In the winter, heating costs are a bigger hit, and I have to use more electricity for lights and the little heater I have. I also noticed that when the holidays come around, like Christmas or Thanksgiving, I end up spending a bit more on groceries because I try to make something special for my family. But then, when the weather gets nicer in the spring and summer, I don't need to use as much heat, and I can save a little. There's also the cost of the online courses I've been taking—those are pretty steady, but they add up over time. I've also had to pay for a few unexpected things, like a new pair of shoes for work or a doctor's visit when my back pain got worse. It's not always easy to plan for these things, but I try to set aside a little money each month just in case. I know it's not perfect, but I'm learning to be more aware of how my expenses change throughout the year, and that helps me stay a little more prepared.

Going through the questions about my family and how I use social media made me think a lot about what really matters in my life. My family has always been my rock, even when things were tough, and I realize now how much their support has helped me keep going. I used to feel like I had to prove myself to the world, but now I see that the people I love are the ones who matter most. As for social media, I guess I've always preferred real connections over virtual ones. I don't need to see what others are doing online to feel connected—I have my family, my friends, and the people in my neighborhood who remind me that I'm not alone. It's funny how something as simple as a late-night talk on the porch or a message from Jamie can make all the difference. I'm learning that I don't need to chase the perfect life online; I just need to be present in the one I have.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Kelly Sullivan: I don't have a formal savings account, and honestly, I haven't really saved in the traditional sense. It's not that I don't want to—it's just that every dollar feels like it's needed right now. I try to save a little here and there, like when I get a bonus from the bookstore or when I finish a big project with Jamie's nonprofit, but it's always so small. I keep it in a jar under my bed, just a few bills and coins, and I tell myself it's for emergencies. I know it's not much, but it gives me a little peace of mind. I guess I'm still learning what it means to save, and I hope one day I can build something more solid. For now, I'm just trying to make sure I don't run out of money before I can get on my feet.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Kelly Sullivan: Honestly, saving for big things like a home feels like something that's way out of reach right now. I know people talk about buying a house or starting a business, but I'm still trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. I don't want to save for something I might not even want in the future. That said, I do try to save a little for emergencies, just in case something happens—like if I lose my job at the bookstore or if my back pain gets worse and I need to see a doctor again. It's not much, but it's something. I guess I'm still learning what saving means for me, and I hope that one day I can look back and see that I was building something, even if it was just a few dollars at a time.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Kelly Sullivan: My occupation right now is part-time work at a small bookstore downtown, and I also do some odd jobs around the neighborhood to make ends meet. At the bookstore, my main duties are helping customers find books, restocking shelves, and keeping the place tidy. It's not a high-pressure job, but I enjoy the quiet and the way the customers often share stories about the books they're reading. I think the most important part of my job is the connection I make with people—whether it's recommending a book that might help them through a tough time or just having a friendly chat while they're browsing. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of purpose. I also do some administrative work for Jamie's nonprofit in the afternoons, which has been a big part of my life lately. It's not the kind of work that pays well, but it feels meaningful, and I know it's helping people in our community. I guess I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life, but for now, these jobs keep me going and give me a chance to learn and grow.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Kelly Sullivan: I usually work around 15 to 20 hours a week at the bookstore, depending on how busy it gets. The owner, Mrs. Thompson, is pretty flexible, and she knows I'm also trying to take some classes and help out with Jamie's nonprofit. Most weeks, I'll work three mornings, maybe 9 to 12, and then a few afternoons doing odd jobs or helping with the nonprofit. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me going. I've been trying to balance work with my studies and volunteering, and it's a tightrope walk sometimes. But I think that's part of the process—learning how to manage my time and not burn myself out. I know I can't do everything at once, but I'm trying to do what I can, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Kelly Sullivan: Yeah, I've had a few different jobs and side gigs over the years, especially when I was trying to figure things out. Besides the bookstore, I've worked at a few retail stores, a diner, and even did some yard work for neighbors. I used to take on as much as I could handle, just to make sure we had enough money. But I think that's one of the things I've learned over time—trying to do everything at once just leads to burnout. Now, I try to be more selective about what I take on, especially since I'm also working on my GED and helping Jamie with her nonprofit. It's a balancing act, but I think it's better to focus on a few things and do them well, rather than spreading myself too thin. I'm still learning what that looks like for me, but I'm trying to be more intentional about how I spend my time and energy.

Going through the recent interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the small, everyday choices I've made—like managing my stress, keeping track of my budget, and finding ways to stay connected with the people who matter most. It's easy to feel like I'm not making progress when I'm just trying to keep up with the basics, but I've started to see that progress doesn't always look like a big leap forward. Sometimes it's about taking one step at a time, even if it's just walking for 20 minutes a day or making sure I eat a proper meal before work. I've also realized how much my family and friends have been there for me, even when I didn't always recognize it. I used to feel like I had to do everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's part of what keeps me going. I'm still learning what it means to be responsible, to save, and to take care of myself, but I'm trying to be more mindful of every dollar I spend and every moment I have. I don't have everything figured out yet, but I'm starting to believe that I can build something better, even if it's just one step at a time.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Kelly Sullivan: In total, my household made around $1,200 last month, give or take. That's mostly from my part-time job at the bookstore and the odd jobs I pick up around the neighborhood. I don't make a lot, but I try to stretch every dollar as much as I can. Sometimes I feel like I'm just barely keeping up, but I know I'm doing the best I can with what I have. I don't want to worry my parents too much, so I try to cover as much of their bills as I can, even if it's just a little. It's not much, but it helps them feel like they're not alone in this. I guess I'm still learning what it means to be responsible, but I'm trying to be more mindful of every dollar I earn and every step I take toward a better future.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Kelly Sullivan: I've been working at the bookstore for about a year now, and it's been a good fit for me. The hours are steady, and the people I work with are pretty easygoing. Mrs. Thompson, the owner, is like a second mother to me—she's always checking in on me, making sure I'm okay, and even letting me take a break when I need to. As for benefits, well, there's not much in the way of health insurance or paid time off. I get a few days off a month, but they're not guaranteed, and I don't have any sick days or vacation days to speak of. It's not much, but I don't mind—it's more about the flexibility and the fact that I can keep working while still trying to take classes and help out with Jamie's nonprofit. I know it's not the most stable job, but it's something I can rely on, and that's enough for now.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Kelly Sullivan: My relationships at work are pretty good, actually. Mrs. Thompson, the owner, is really kind and understanding. She knows I'm juggling a lot—work, school, and helping Jamie with her nonprofit—and she's always been supportive. She doesn't push me too hard, and she lets me take breaks when I need to, which is something I really appreciate. As for the other staff, there are a couple of regulars who I've gotten to know pretty well. We don't talk much, but we're friendly, and they always make sure I have a smile on my face when I'm feeling down. It's not a high-pressure environment, and that's exactly what I need right now. I don't need a lot of drama or stress at work—I just want to feel like I'm doing something that matters, even if it's just helping someone find the right book or having a quick chat with a customer. I think that's why I keep coming back, even when the pay isn't great. It's the people, the quiet, and the little moments that make it feel like home.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Kelly Sullivan: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I really appreciate about the bookstore. Mrs. Thompson lets me know when she needs me in, and I usually work mornings from 9 to 12, but sometimes I can adjust if I need to be somewhere else in the afternoon. It's not the kind of job where I have to be there at the exact same time every day, which is a relief because I'm also trying to balance my GED classes, helping Jamie with her nonprofit, and taking care of my family. I don't mind working irregular hours as long as I can still make it to the things that matter. It's not perfect, but it gives me the freedom to manage my time in a way that works for me, even if it means sometimes working late or taking a day off when I need to rest.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Kelly Sullivan: Overall, I feel like I'm in a holding pattern, you know? It's not that I'm unhappy or dissatisfied—it's more like I'm waiting for something to click into place. I know I'm making progress, even if it's slow. I passed my GED, I'm helping Jamie with her nonprofit, and I'm learning new things every day. But I also know that I'm not where I want to be yet. I want to have more stability, more security, and a future that feels like it's mine. Right now, I'm trying to focus on what I can control—my work, my studies, and the people I care about. I know it's not easy, and I know I don't have all the answers, but I'm trying to believe that if I keep moving forward, even one step at a time, I'll get there eventually.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours made me realize how much I've been juggling just to keep things going. It's not that I don't want to plan for the future—it's just that every dollar feels like it's needed right now. I've been trying to save a little, even if it's just in a jar under my bed, and I'm learning to track my expenses better, especially with the seasonal changes affecting my heating and grocery costs. My work at the bookstore gives me some flexibility, but it's not a lot of money, and I know I'm still figuring out what it means to be responsible with my time and money. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm trying to take it one step at a time, and that's something I can hold on to.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Kelly Sullivan: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked construction, mostly on local projects, and my mom worked part-time at a small store downtown. They both worked hard, even though they only made it through high school. I remember seeing my dad come home tired after long days on the job, and my mom always had to juggle work with taking care of us. It wasn't easy for them, but they never complained. They always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads, even when money was tight. I think that's why I always felt like I had to prove myself—because they gave me so much without asking for anything in return. I want to make sure I can give my brother Sean the same kind of support they gave me, even if I'm still figuring out how to do it myself.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Kelly Sullivan: My dad worked construction, mostly on local projects—roads, buildings, that kind of thing. He was the kind of guy who got his hands dirty and never asked for much in return. His most important duties were showing up on time, doing the job right, and making sure the crew stayed safe. He wasn't one for fancy tools or complicated plans—he just knew how to build things, and he took pride in that. My mom worked part-time at a small store downtown, mostly in the back, restocking shelves and helping with inventory. She was always organized, even when things got busy. Her most important duties were making sure the store ran smoothly and that the customers got what they needed. Both of them had their own way of doing things, but they both worked hard to give us a better life, even when they didn't have much to give themselves. I think that's why I always felt like I had to do better than them, not because I wanted to leave them behind, but because I wanted to make sure they didn't have to struggle the way they did.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Kelly Sullivan: My dad worked for a local construction company that handled everything from road repairs to small building projects. They weren't a big corporation, just a family-run business with a few guys who knew how to get the job done. He was one of the guys on the crew, and he didn't have a lot of fancy tools or certifications—just a strong back and a willingness to work hard. My mom worked at a small grocery store downtown, one of those old-fashioned places where the owner still knew everyone by name. She was in the back, restocking shelves, managing inventory, and making sure the store stayed open even when things got busy. They both made enough to get by, but not much more than that. I remember watching them work, seeing how tired they got, and knowing that they were doing it all for us. I think that's why I always felt like I had to do better than them—not because I wanted to leave them behind, but because I wanted to make sure they didn't have to struggle the way they did.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Kelly Sullivan: I hope that in a few years, I'm still in Charleston, but maybe with a little more stability in my life. I don't know if I'll have a big job or a fancy house, but I hope I'm doing something that matters—something that helps people, like Jamie's nonprofit or maybe even something bigger. I hope I've finished my GED and maybe even started taking some classes at the community college. I want to be in a place where I can support my family without worrying so much about money, and I hope my brother Sean is doing well in college and that we can still have those late-night talks on the porch like we used to. I also hope I'm healthier, not just physically but mentally, and that I've learned how to take care of myself without pushing everything aside. I don't know what the future holds, but I hope it's one where I feel like I've made something of myself—not because I'm better than anyone else, but because I've kept going, even when it was hard.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Kelly Sullivan: What I value the most in my life is the people who have stood by me through everything—my family, Jamie, and even the people in my neighborhood who I don't always know by name but who still look out for each other. I think I've always known that I didn't have much in terms of money or opportunities, but I've always had this sense of belonging, this quiet strength that comes from knowing I'm not alone. I value the little things—the late-night talks on the porch, the way my mom always makes sure I have a meal before I leave for work, the way my brother still believes in me even when I don't believe in myself. I value the fact that I'm still trying, even when it's hard, and that I'm learning to take care of myself in ways I never thought possible. I don't know what the future holds, but I know that as long as I have these people in my life, I'll keep going, one step at a time.

Going through the questions about my work and relationships at the bookstore made me realize how much my job has become more than just a way to make ends meet. It's a place where I feel seen and supported, even if it's not a perfect job. Mrs. Thompson and the other staff have been like a second family to me, and that sense of belonging matters more than I ever thought it would. I used to think I needed a bigger, better job to feel like I was making progress, but now I see that it's the small, steady things—like having a flexible schedule, being able to take breaks when I need to, and working with people who care—that help me keep going. I'm still figuring out what I want for my future, but I'm learning that it's okay to be where I am right now, as long as I'm moving forward, even if it's just one step at a time.

Going through this complete interview and life story has made me realize how much I've grown, even if I'm still figuring things out. It's been a journey of small steps—like deciding to leave Charleston after high school, enrolling in the GED program, and finding purpose in helping others through Jamie's nonprofit. I used to feel like I was stuck in a cycle, but now I see that every challenge I've faced has shaped who I am today. I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, that progress doesn't always look like a big leap forward, and that the people I love are the ones who have kept me going. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I'm trying to believe that with every step I take, I'm moving closer to a future that feels like mine. I'm grateful for the people who've stood by me, for the lessons I've learned, and for the strength I've found in the little things. This interview has reminded me that I don't have to have everything figured out to keep going—I just have to keep moving forward, one step at a time.
